body:
Hello, 
  I was just wondering, are you allowed to cover your monument with wood so it makes it harder for enemies to get to it? Or would that be considered an infraction? 
This person clearly wasn't thinking, we had a iron axe that could quickly break the wood.
Thx for the help!
body_tagged:

This person clearly wasn't thinking, we had a iron axe that could quickly break the wood.
Thx for the help!
title: Quick Question

replies.body: You may although it is a bad idea strategically. This can pnly be an infraction if ruins a pre-existing defence
replies.body_tagged: You may although it is a bad idea strategically. This can pnly be an infraction if ruins a pre-existing defence

replies.body: Why don't people understand that putting wood around a monument is the most stupid Minecraft tactic that anyone has ever invented?
replies.body_tagged: Why don't people understand that putting wood around a monument is the most stupid Minecraft tactic that anyone has ever invented?

replies.body: Okay Thx for the help, it is a stupid tactic though, ppl can hide inside the wood while destroying the monument
replies.body_tagged: Okay Thx for the help, it is a stupid tactic though, ppl can hide inside the wood while destroying the monument

replies.body: If you already made your defences and someone in your team comes along and places wood everywhere or removes yours to put their own, it's griefing and should be reported.
replies.body_tagged: If you already made your defences and someone in your team comes along and places wood everywhere or removes yours to put their own, it's griefing and should be reported.

replies.body: Its considered an infraction if you remove a defense system that was already in place. In my opinion this is not a very strategic way of defending a monument, as an enemy can mine it from below or above without you noticing.
replies.body_tagged: Its considered an infraction if you remove a defense system that was already in place. In my opinion this is not a very strategic way of defending a monument, as an enemy can mine it from below or above without you noticing.

replies.body: It is considered illegal when it turns into Team Griefing. So when you "destroy" someone else's defence it becomes illegal.
replies.body_tagged: It is considered illegal when it turns into Team Griefing. So when you "destroy" someone else's defence it becomes illegal.

replies.body: It's generally a bad tactic, but covering with wood is basically the only way to defend on a map like Dust Devils OiTN, since if you don't, it's pretty much instant break.
replies.body_tagged: It's generally a bad tactic, but covering with wood is basically the only way to defend on a map like Dust Devils OiTN, since if you don't, it's pretty much instant break.

replies.body: Covering the moneument isn't the greatest of decision. It acts as a hiding spot for the opposition. When ever i see this is makes my blood boil. Try to make a defense where the monuement is visible at all times.
replies.body_tagged: Covering the moneument isn't the greatest of decision. It acts as a hiding spot for the opposition. When ever i see this is makes my blood boil. Try to make a defense where the monuement is visible at all times.

replies.body: Not an infraction. It's a great idea ;) *coughcoughdefinatelynotarushercoughcough*
replies.body_tagged: Not an infraction. It's a great idea ;) *coughcoughdefinatelynotarushercoughcough*

replies.body: Yes, I am not much of a rusher, although sometimes I like to try and break enemy monuments
replies.body_tagged: Yes, I am not much of a rusher, although sometimes I like to try and break enemy monuments

replies.body:
You can cover the monument in wood.

But.
I highly suggest you don't. Here are my reasons:
  • For most maps, it's a bad strategy. The enemy can hide inside the wood while sneaking, meaning they can break the monument without anybody noticing. Good rushers can sneak in quite easily, and practically anyone can get a wood-covered monument
  • People that know this strategy is bad (regulars) will absolutely rage at you to NOT cover the monument. It's not against the rules, no, but as I mentioned, it's a bad strategy and it will most likely put you in a disadvantaged situation.
  • As a moderator, I tend to get quite a few reports labeled "team griefing," but in fact it is only a few people arguing whether to cover the monument or not. It's honestly a real pain to deal with, and while I can usually resolve the situation, it's not something I (and other staff) enjoy doing on a regular basis.
In short:
You can cover the monument if you want.
But I highly recommend you don't.

Hope this helps! ^-^

It's honestly a real pain to deal with, and while I can usually resolve the situation, it's not something I (and other staff) enjoy doing on a regular basis.
In short:

But I highly recommend you don't.

Hope this helps! ^-^

replies.body:
Any defense is better than no defense.

What makes a defense good is a combination of a natural defense and players that are nearby and guard it.
replies.body_tagged:
Any defense is better than no defense.

What makes a defense good is a combination of a natural defense and players that are nearby and guard it.

reply_to.body: It's arguable. You could say that you'd rather have no defence than have a hiding spot for rushers
reply_to.body_tagged: It's arguable. You could say that you'd rather have no defence than have a hiding spot for rushers

replies.body:
As Snow said, any defense is better than no defense. 
But really, this defense is so weak, it's like building a house of sand next to the water. When the waves come crashing in, the whole house will collapse because there is no strong foundation. 

Covering the monument is one of the weakest forms of defense in Nebula, mainly because people think:

  • Monument's "protected."
  • Because it's "Protected," who needs to guard? 
  • "Covering in lots of wood will definitely stop the enemy in his tracks.
One of the better things to do would be to leave the monument, remove all the things around it (doesn't include bedrock), and create a defense using an assortment of fences, pressure plates, crafting tables, and well-armoured players standing guard.

  • "Covering in lots of wood will definitely stop the enemy in his tracks.
One of the better things to do would be to leave the monument, remove all the things around it (doesn't include bedrock), and create a defense using an assortment of fences, pressure plates, crafting tables, and well-armoured players standing guard.
